summary: Fic: Tipsy in a Push Up Bra, Pt 2
title: Fic: Tipsy in a Push Up Bra, Pt 2
body:
Jon x Sansa - Tipsy high school Sansa in a red push up bra. What could go wrong? / Part 1

Sansa looks up and realizes Jon is watching her in the quiet, careful way he had outside Margaery’s house, like she’s a bird with a broken wing. She tears her gaze away, a cold knot clenched in her gut. After Joffrey she’d sworn she would never do this again. “You don’t have to take care of me,” she blurts. “I can get one of my friends to give me a ride.”

Jon takes off in the opposite direction from the other kids, back along the house and a gate that opens up into a neighbor’s side yard, Sansa stumbling after him. They slip through the dark into a back street and then Sansa loses track of where they are or where they’re going, all the streets blending together into a dark maze. A few minutes of the wind whipping her hair and Jon pulls her to stop a next to a darkened park. “This should be good,” he says, barely breathing hard. “Who was your ride?”

There’s a playground just inside the park, and Sansa slumps to a seat on one of the empty swings, curls her fingers around the frigid and dusty chains. “Margaery. But that was her house.”

Jon stuffs his hands in his pockets against the cold. His breath mists the air. “Arya said you’re staying with your aunt. What about her?”

“I told her I was spending the night at Margaery’s.” The cold has peeled away some of the peach schnapps’ tingling warmth, and Sansa finds herself missing it desperately. Calling Lysa for a ride isn’t an option even in the best of circumstances much less late at night to be picked up from an abandoned park, but she doesn’t want to admit that to Jon, doesn’t want to do anything to look more pathetic than she already has. I can text one of my friends, she thinks of offering, but that would be a lie. She’d had people she thought were friends in her old life, but they’d all shriveled up and disappeared after she could no longer keep up with their lifestyle, and she knows better than to think the people she goes to school with here are her friends.

She looks up and realizes Jon is watching her in the quiet, careful way he had outside Margaery’s house, like she’s a bird with a broken wing. Sansa tears her gaze away, a cold knot clenched in her gut. After Joffrey she’d sworn she would never do this again, never let anyone see her like this. “You don’t have to take care of me,” she blurts. “I can get one of my friends to give me a ride.”

“Don’t worry about it. Robb would’ve killed me if-” A muscle twitches in Jon’s jaw and he shakes his head. He pulls his phone from his pocket. “It’s not a problem. Theon was my ride, I’ll get him to come pick us up.”

Sansa nods, but a lump’s risen to her throat at Robb’s name, and it refuses to bob back down as Jon takes the swing next to her, hands thrust into his pockets. Cold minute after cold minute ticks by without Jon’s phone chirping until Sansa doesn’t think she can stand it any longer. She wraps her arms around herself, shoves her hands into her armpits. “Have you talked to Bran?” She asks without looking at him.

Jon is silent a long moment. “Not for awhile,” he finally answers. “I wanted to see him more, you know after, but-” a rustling sound like he’s shaking his head. “Catelyn isn’t the biggest fan of mine.”

Sansa remembers that about the funeral at least: the way Arya had clung to Jon with his sling the whole time and the way her mother had watched him coldly, silently judging, silently asking why he’d been the one to survive. She’d never liked Jon. Maybe that was why Sansa had never liked him either. She’d wanted so desperately to be like her mother when she was young; Catelyn who was effortlessly graceful always. Idly, Sansa wonders when that stopped, when she turned into the girl who goes to parties and gets tipsy on schnapps so she won’t feel nauseous when guys grind up against her on the dance floor, who ends up in an abandoned park at midnight with a stranger.

Not a stranger. Jon.

Jon slips his phone out to check it, mutters a particularly imaginative combination of four letter words, and stands up. “My place is about a mile from here,” he says, running his fingers through his hair. “We can wait there, if you want. I think Theon found a girl so it may be a bit.”

Sansa nods mutely, too cold to do more, and stands. They leave the park behind, streetlights flooding the sidewalk in pools of yellow halogen light. Though not the highest heels she owns, Sansa’s feet ache almost immediately.

“Hold up,” she tells Jon after a few minutes. She reaches up and grabs his shoulder, and maybe it’s the last hurrah of schnapps left in her veins, but she can’t help but notice how muscled it is, the way his tendons shift under her fingers as he reaches a hand to steady her. And she can’t help but notice the way his eyes slide to her chest as she does and the way the platter of her cleavage jiggles as she balances on one foot and then the other to slip off her heels.

“All good?” Jon asks with a faint smile, eyes flicking guiltily back to her face.

“All good,” she agrees with a smile of own, heels dangling from her fingers.

—

It take maybe another ten minutes of walking to reach Jon’s apartment. Jon fumbles with his keys when they reach the stairwell, then pulls open the door and holds it open for her. It’s too dark to see anything inside until Jon hit a few switches on the wall and light flickers on to show a small but relatively neat apartment, a third of the space taken up by a kitchenette and island.

Sansa uncrosses her arms and rubs her hands together as Jon moves to the thermostat on the opposite wall. She starts wandering around as he fiddles with it. “Sorry,” Jon mutters. A second later a gust of hot air rattles the vent overhead. “It’ll heat up soon.”

Sansa nods absentmindedly, only half listening, still taking in the small space. Outside of the kitchenette there’s a vaguely second hand couch, a nicked and dented coffee table, a flatscreen on the far wall, and Theon’s Iron Island band posters plastered across the walls. It’s a guy’s setup: clean enough to invite girls over to, but no real thought in any of the details. But that wasn’t fair: was her room at Lysa’s really any different? Even after a year it still feels empty and strange, not truly hers. Her room is back in the old house, lying on her stomach scribbling in her diary on her bed or standing on the tips of his toes in front of her mirror to do her makeup before school.

“I know it’s not a lot,” Jon rubs the back of his neck as he watches her wander around the room, “but it’s close to Castle Black. Saves me having to drive a lot.”

“I’m not judging.” Sansa forces a laugh. “My Berkeley plan died about the same time as my college fund dried up.”

Jon is silent as she finishes wandering around the room. “What happened with that?” He asks as she circles back to where she started. “I heard some of it from Arya, but you know how she is with… details.”

Sansa bites her lip. She glances at the door beside where Jon leans against the wall, because if she looks at him something in her will crack and break and, though she doesn’t know why, of everyone in the world in this moment she doesn’t want Jon to see that. “Is that your room?”

He nods silently, and she crosses the room, pushes the door open and slips inside still without looking at him. The space inside is maybe a quarter the size of the pink and pastel blue one she’d had back in Winterfell, his bed taking up a majority of the floor. There’s a half open closet next to it, and on the wall are thumbtacked a few of the weird drawings Arya instagrams sometimes.

Something about them makes Sansa tired and her chest ache, and she folds her legs under her and sinks to the floor at the foot of Jon’s bed, cool wood knuckling into her back. Jon goes to flip the light on, then pauses. Out of the side of her eye she sees him let his arm drop, and he moves to the foot of the bed. She feels more than sees him slide down to the carpet beside her, legs drawn up to fit in the narrow space between bed and wall.

“Give me your hand,” she says, still not looking at him. He hesitates, then offers it, and Sansa draws it to her lap. It’s warm and solid, calluses rasping lightly against the tips of her fingers as she ghosts them over his palm. “What did Arya tell you?”

“That your dad had been floating money for his business partner. Baratheon, I think.”

“Robert Baratheon.” She traces the half circle running from his wrist to above his thumb. It’s easier than looking up. “After the crash…”

And sitting with his shoulder touching hers and his hand in her lap, Sansa tells him. Tells him how when her mother had needed the money back Robert hadn’t had it, how after the feds shut him down it meant they were never getting any of it back, how it had taken selling the house and cashing in her father’s life insurance and every cent they had invested just to cover the clients Robert cheated, how even that had barely been enough to keep them from being sued.

And once she’s started Sansa finds she can’t stop: she tells him about how even though he’d survived the crash Bran’s medical bills had drained their savings dry, how her mother had gone back to work only to find she didn’t make enough to cover them, how Arya had almost been expelled from school for getting in fights, how every friend Sansa thought she’d had disappeared like smoke once she couldn’t keep up with their clothes and shoes and purses, how she’d stayed for so long with Joffrey before breaking up because she didn’t know who she was without him, how she’d had to move in with Lysa just so she could have a shot at the Vale High transfer scholarship and a decent college.

Jon listens through it all without speaking, a solid presence beside her, hand callused and warm. When the words have finally run dry he touches her knee. “I’m sorry,” he says, voice soft and hoarse. “I didn’t know. I should’ve been there. But after the crash, with your mom and Bran- I didn’t feel like it was my place-”

“I know. It’s ok.” Sansa gives him a smile; sad and small, but it’s the last she has. “You were there for Arya. I don’t think she could have gotten through it without you.”

“Yeah, but…” Jon’s jaw works silently. “Someone should have been there for you.”

“I managed.” Sansa looks back down at his palm. It is isn’t fair for her to do it, not when they were never close, not when he’s just being kind (and Jon has always been kind, even if she never bothered to notice), but Sansa pulls his arm over her shoulders and shifts so she fits in the crook of his side. “I always manage.”

“Sansa…” He starts, and Sansa thinks his voice may be the saddest thing she’s ever heard. She shakes her head into his shoulder before he can say more. She’s snug and safe, snug and safe for the first time in a long time and she doesn’t want to give that up for something that is dead and gone. They aren’t friends, she knows that, she does, but-

“Jon,” she says softly, “can we just sit for a little?”

Jon is still a long moment, then nods into her hair and pulls her closer.

She feels more than sees him slide down to the carpet beside her, legs drawn up to fit in the narrow space between bed and wall.

“Give me your hand,” she says, still not looking at him. He hesitates, then offers it, and Sansa draws it to her lap. It’s warm and solid, calluses rasping lightly against the tips of her fingers as she ghosts them over his palm. “What did Arya tell you?”

“That your dad had been floating money for his business partner. Baratheon, I think.”

“Robert Baratheon.” She traces the half circle running from his wrist to above his thumb. It’s easier than looking up. “After the crash…”

And sitting with his shoulder touching hers and his hand in her lap, Sansa tells him. Tells him how when her mother had needed the money back Robert hadn’t had it, how after the feds shut him down it meant they were never getting any of it back, how it had taken selling the house and cashing in her father’s life insurance and every cent they had invested just to cover the clients Robert cheated, how even that had barely been enough to keep them from being sued.

And once she’s started Sansa finds she can’t stop: she tells him about how even though he’d survived the crash Bran’s medical bills had drained their savings dry, how her mother had gone back to work only to find she didn’t make enough to cover them, how Arya had almost been expelled from school for getting in fights, how every friend Sansa thought she’d had disappeared like smoke once she couldn’t keep up with their clothes and shoes and purses, how she’d stayed for so long with Joffrey before breaking up because she didn’t know who she was without him, how she’d had to move in with Lysa just so she could have a shot at the Vale High transfer scholarship and a decent college.

Jon listens through it all without speaking, a solid presence beside her, hand callused and warm. When the words have finally run dry he touches her knee. “I’m sorry,” he says, voice soft and hoarse. “I didn’t know. I should’ve been there. But after the crash, with your mom and Bran- I didn’t feel like it was my place-”

“I know. It’s ok.” Sansa gives him a smile; sad and small, but it’s the last she has. “You were there for Arya. I don’t think she could have gotten through it without you.”

“Yeah, but…” Jon’s jaw works silently. “Someone should have been there for you.”

“I managed.” Sansa looks back down at his palm. It is isn’t fair for her to do it, not when they were never close, not when he’s just being kind (and Jon has always been kind, even if she never bothered to notice), but Sansa pulls his arm over her shoulders and shifts so she fits in the crook of his side. “I always manage.”

“Sansa…” He starts, and Sansa thinks his voice may be the saddest thing she’s ever heard. She shakes her head into his shoulder before he can say more. She’s snug and safe, snug and safe for the first time in a long time and she doesn’t want to give that up for something that is dead and gone. They aren’t friends, she knows that, she does, but-

“Jon,” she says softly, “can we just sit for a little?”

Jon is still a long moment, then nods into her hair and pulls her closer.

trail.content:
Jon x Sansa - Tipsy high school Sansa in a red push up bra. What could go wrong? / Part 1

Sansa looks up and realizes Jon is watching her in the quiet, careful way he had outside Margaery’s house, like she’s a bird with a broken wing. She tears her gaze away, a cold knot clenched in her gut. After Joffrey she’d sworn she would never do this again. “You don’t have to take care of me,” she blurts. “I can get one of my friends to give me a ride.”

Jon takes off in the opposite direction from the other kids, back along the house and a gate that opens up into a neighbor’s side yard, Sansa stumbling after him. They slip through the dark into a back street and then Sansa loses track of where they are or where they’re going, all the streets blending together into a dark maze. A few minutes of the wind whipping her hair and Jon pulls her to stop a next to a darkened park. “This should be good,” he says, barely breathing hard. “Who was your ride?”

There’s a playground just inside the park, and Sansa slumps to a seat on one of the empty swings, curls her fingers around the frigid and dusty chains. “Margaery. But that was her house.”

Jon stuffs his hands in his pockets against the cold. His breath mists the air. “Arya said you’re staying with your aunt. What about her?”

“I told her I was spending the night at Margaery’s.” The cold has peeled away some of the peach schnapps’ tingling warmth, and Sansa finds herself missing it desperately. Calling Lysa for a ride isn’t an option even in the best of circumstances much less late at night to be picked up from an abandoned park, but she doesn’t want to admit that to Jon, doesn’t want to do anything to look more pathetic than she already has. I can text one of my friends, she thinks of offering, but that would be a lie. She’d had people she thought were friends in her old life, but they’d all shriveled up and disappeared after she could no longer keep up with their lifestyle, and she knows better than to think the people she goes to school with here are her friends.

She looks up and realizes Jon is watching her in the quiet, careful way he had outside Margaery’s house, like she’s a bird with a broken wing. Sansa tears her gaze away, a cold knot clenched in her gut. After Joffrey she’d sworn she would never do this again, never let anyone see her like this. “You don’t have to take care of me,” she blurts. “I can get one of my friends to give me a ride.”

“Don’t worry about it. Robb would’ve killed me if-” A muscle twitches in Jon’s jaw and he shakes his head. He pulls his phone from his pocket. “It’s not a problem. Theon was my ride, I’ll get him to come pick us up.”

Sansa nods, but a lump’s risen to her throat at Robb’s name, and it refuses to bob back down as Jon takes the swing next to her, hands thrust into his pockets. Cold minute after cold minute ticks by without Jon’s phone chirping until Sansa doesn’t think she can stand it any longer. She wraps her arms around herself, shoves her hands into her armpits. “Have you talked to Bran?” She asks without looking at him.

Jon is silent a long moment. “Not for awhile,” he finally answers. “I wanted to see him more, you know after, but-” a rustling sound like he’s shaking his head. “Catelyn isn’t the biggest fan of mine.”

Sansa remembers that about the funeral at least: the way Arya had clung to Jon with his sling the whole time and the way her mother had watched him coldly, silently judging, silently asking why he’d been the one to survive. She’d never liked Jon. Maybe that was why Sansa had never liked him either. She’d wanted so desperately to be like her mother when she was young; Catelyn who was effortlessly graceful always. Idly, Sansa wonders when that stopped, when she turned into the girl who goes to parties and gets tipsy on schnapps so she won’t feel nauseous when guys grind up against her on the dance floor, who ends up in an abandoned park at midnight with a stranger.

Not a stranger. Jon.

Jon slips his phone out to check it, mutters a particularly imaginative combination of four letter words, and stands up. “My place is about a mile from here,” he says, running his fingers through his hair. “We can wait there, if you want. I think Theon found a girl so it may be a bit.”

Sansa nods mutely, too cold to do more, and stands. They leave the park behind, streetlights flooding the sidewalk in pools of yellow halogen light. Though not the highest heels she owns, Sansa’s feet ache almost immediately.

“Hold up,” she tells Jon after a few minutes. She reaches up and grabs his shoulder, and maybe it’s the last hurrah of schnapps left in her veins, but she can’t help but notice how muscled it is, the way his tendons shift under her fingers as he reaches a hand to steady her. And she can’t help but notice the way his eyes slide to her chest as she does and the way the platter of her cleavage jiggles as she balances on one foot and then the other to slip off her heels.

“All good?” Jon asks with a faint smile, eyes flicking guiltily back to her face.

“All good,” she agrees with a smile of own, heels dangling from her fingers.

—

It take maybe another ten minutes of walking to reach Jon’s apartment. Jon fumbles with his keys when they reach the stairwell, then pulls open the door and holds it open for her. It’s too dark to see anything inside until Jon hit a few switches on the wall and light flickers on to show a small but relatively neat apartment, a third of the space taken up by a kitchenette and island.

Sansa uncrosses her arms and rubs her hands together as Jon moves to the thermostat on the opposite wall. She starts wandering around as he fiddles with it. “Sorry,” Jon mutters. A second later a gust of hot air rattles the vent overhead. “It’ll heat up soon.”

Sansa nods absentmindedly, only half listening, still taking in the small space. Outside of the kitchenette there’s a vaguely second hand couch, a nicked and dented coffee table, a flatscreen on the far wall, and Theon’s Iron Island band posters plastered across the walls. It’s a guy’s setup: clean enough to invite girls over to, but no real thought in any of the details. But that wasn’t fair: was her room at Lysa’s really any different? Even after a year it still feels empty and strange, not truly hers. Her room is back in the old house, lying on her stomach scribbling in her diary on her bed or standing on the tips of his toes in front of her mirror to do her makeup before school.

“I know it’s not a lot,” Jon rubs the back of his neck as he watches her wander around the room, “but it’s close to Castle Black. Saves me having to drive a lot.”

“I’m not judging.” Sansa forces a laugh. “My Berkeley plan died about the same time as my college fund dried up.”

Jon is silent as she finishes wandering around the room. “What happened with that?” He asks as she circles back to where she started. “I heard some of it from Arya, but you know how she is with… details.”

Sansa bites her lip. She glances at the door beside where Jon leans against the wall, because if she looks at him something in her will crack and break and, though she doesn’t know why, of everyone in the world in this moment she doesn’t want Jon to see that. “Is that your room?”

He nods silently, and she crosses the room, pushes the door open and slips inside still without looking at him. The space inside is maybe a quarter the size of the pink and pastel blue one she’d had back in Winterfell, his bed taking up a majority of the floor. There’s a half open closet next to it, and on the wall are thumbtacked a few of the weird drawings Arya instagrams sometimes.

Something about them makes Sansa tired and her chest ache, and she folds her legs under her and sinks to the floor at the foot of Jon’s bed, cool wood knuckling into her back. Jon goes to flip the light on, then pauses. Out of the side of her eye she sees him let his arm drop, and he moves to the foot of the bed. She feels more than sees him slide down to the carpet beside her, legs drawn up to fit in the narrow space between bed and wall.

summary: Wait . . . is Robb older than Jon? Someone explain the full timeline please because It just occurred to me that Jon never knew...
body:
Wait … is Robb older than Jon?

Someone explain the full timeline please because It just occurred to me that Jon never knew his true age because Robb was fathered in the eve of Ned and Catelyn’s wedding while Jon was conceived a bit earlier than Ned’s supposed infidelity and all this leads me to think that Ned had to lie a bit about Jon’s birthday … though maybe not? 

Also, how far apart are the tower of joy combat and the assault on Dragonstone?

summary: A Northern Light - Help me if you can. Thank you
title: A Northern Light - Help me if you can. Thank you
body:
(A Robb Stark x reader multi-chapter series)

I would like to send out my thanks to those of you who took the time to send in mood boards for my chapter series ‘A Northern Light’.  You guys did some beautiful work on them, but unfortunately, I can only choose one.  The one I ended up picking was from a lovely follower who would prefer to stay anonymous, thank you, it’s perfect.

Here it is

Original post below

So I hope you guys are enjoying the series so far, because I have enjoyed writing it, but there is a long way to go yet and I would like your help.

What I would like to do is get rid of the gifs at the beginning of each chapter and replace it with a mood board or something which I can use exclusively for ‘A Northern Light’.  And I would love for one of you guys to create it for me.

If you’re interested please send your creation in, I would love to see what you’ve got, I will then go through them all and pick my favourite.

Here is what I would like included:

  1. A picture of Robb of course
  2. A picture of the reader (non-specific, it needs to be a silhouette or something that doesn’t show a face, etc, etc)
  3. A picture of Jon Snow (He will be an integral part of the story later down the track.
  4. I would love the reader’s sigil included (snowy owl)
  5. I’ll leave the rest up to you wonderful people, things like wintery scenes, white walkers, Winterfell, Godswoods, whatever you feel suits.
  6. Lastly, if you feel comfortable, sign it, so you can get all the credit for your wonderful creation.
  7. Even if you have a completely different idea, show me, I might love it.

Thank you in advance to anyone who would like to take part

TAGS @tessimagines @falling-stars-never-cry @maiabiovillage @majlin @givemeanorigami @badasseddy @sj-thefan @oliolioxiclean @disneyprincessbuffyannesummers @heyohheyitsgabi

title: I need to share you very important details from season 8 teaser ...Please share everyone ....!!!!!!
body:
This is what I was always talking about . Sansa who betryed to Ned stark and informed Cersei about his planns in season 1.  She told to Cersei that Ned  planned to escape from Kings Landing 

There is a very interesting detail. Nobody knows about that in North. neither Arya,Jon or …Probably Bran knows about that. Why nobody spoke about that during 7 season?
Do you remember what happened after Sansa’s action? Cersei’s people mudrered Northern people who acompaned to Ned Stark from Winterfell. There were 300  man…
There is very special detail. who Knows about Sansas betrayal action? there is only 3 character stil alive: Cersei,Tyrion and Varys.
Tyrion and Varys are #TeamDany. Cersei is their enemy. 
she wants to break Stark house. what is the best maner for that?Tell the Starks that Sansa betrayed their father and he became a prissioner because of Sansa. 
look at this scene where Cersei meet to Jon 

is Cersei teling about Sansa to Jon?
Look at this season 8 teaser. there is very special detail’s from Ned Stark’s execution. There is two scene from Ned Starks’s death.
look …just look 

Do you remember Arya’s words to Sansa in season 7? 

ARYA: We both wanted to be other people when we were younger. You wanted to be a Queen, to sit next to a handsome Prince on the Iron Throne. I wanted to be a knight: to pick up a sword, like Father, and go off to battle. Neither of us got to be the other person, did we? The world doesn’t just let girls decide what they’re going to be. But I can, now. With the Faces, I can choose… I can become someone else. Speak in their voice, live in their skin. I could even become you.

(She mentioned Ned there too. with Sansa)

scene from season 7 where Arya read Sansa’s letter. This is letter from Cersei after Sansa informed about Ned. Why the used this detail ? 

Arya to Sansa: I would have let them to kill me before I betrayed my family …I remember you standing on that platform with Joffry and Cersei when thet dragged father to the block. I remember pretty dress you were wearing ….(Arya mentioned her father Ned Stark again.and especially his death  )

and another scene from season 8 teaser 

Arya Stark looked her father’s death

look at return of the Bran Stark in Winterfell. His meeting with Sansa. No emotion with his face. 

different from Sansa Bran hugged to Arya and Smiled 

But what happened when Bran gave a knife to Arya? He looked at Sansa exactly in this scene . 

And finaly. HBO realised season 8 posters and there is only 3 Stark :Arya,Jon and Bran. The puck survive ,but Lone wolf die …

There is no Sansa poster from House Stark. she is a lone walf and it’s fact. 

Cersei tells Jon about Sansa’s  betrayal.

And you think that someone will hear her explenation in north? 
‘‘I was a child?’‘ There were killed 300 northern men for Sansa. Ned Stark became a prisioner for her stupidity. Can you imagined Jon and Arya reaction about that?

summary:
Jonerys baby was spoler from season 2?
Inside book Rhaego was always silver-blonde. In Dany’s mind  Rhaego was always silver not...
body:
Jonerys baby was spoler from season 2?

Inside book Rhaego was always silver-blonde. In Dany’s mind Rhaego was always silver not a dark. Dany always imagied him with Targaryen looks

But what happened to serie? Look at this foto. Rhaego is dark haur baby.

Especially in book this scene no existing. There is Rhaegar and Ellia with Aegon. D&D add this scene with their decision. But why is Rhaego different from the book.?

We can looked back in season one.

Episode where Dany found her pregnacy.

Episode name is “Lord Snow”

Rhaegos name comes from Rhaegar Targaryen who is true father of Jon Snow.

Dany looked Rhaego in her vision beyond the wall. Dany and Jon story started Beyond the wall. And this Baby wasn’t like real Rhaego from book. This baby is like Jon .

Do you think that showrunners changed this baby without reason?

Oh my sweet summer childs😋🤭❤️

blog.title: Jak O' the Shadows
blog.description: I’m not going to swear an oath I can’t uphold. Talk about my father if you want. Tell me that’s the attitude that got him killed. But when enough people make false promises, words stop meaning anything. Then there are no more answers - only better and better lies. And lies won’t help us in this fight - Jon Snow.

tags: They really want Jon to get stabbed to death by his own men
The character deserves better than the shit he gets from his so called fans
summary: Taken from the political Jon discourse on that tag (That tag is such a misrepresentation of the Jon is who is actually...
body:
Taken from the political Jon discourse on that tag (That tag is such a misrepresentation of the Jon is who is actually politcally savvy but has been turned into LF 2.0 by Sansa stans). Jon Snow fans should remember that this is how Jonsa fans see Jon Snow on the show:

The show hammers the fool/Jon connection, and how Jon appears to be walking in Ned and Robb’s footsteps. But to what degree he is repeating their mistakes is very much up to debate. Thus far in S7, Jon’s mistakes include being tricked into thinking he can rely on a friend (Tyrion) when going south, just like Ned thinking he could rely on a friend (Robert) to shield him. Making the Wall fall and creating an Ice Dragon could also be laid at his feet (although I think Dany is primarily responsible). Now in this entire fiasco, he’s also fallen in love with the woman who wants to burn people alive. It’s just too much foolery for one character. From a Doylist standpoint, if Ned and Robb weren’t allowed to live, Jon should be stabbed by his own men as soon as he steps foot in Winterfell.  

If Jon is not sexually manipulating Dany and in love with Sansa, Jon should be stabbed to death by the Northerners in Winterfell - that is literally what these guys think should happen to the Jon who has bend the knee to Dany and fallen in love with her! You guys think the Dany hate is bad? Wait till season 8 for Jon Snow to get some rabid, vitriolic hate from the Jonsa/Sansa stans who just cannot seem to accept that Jon really, really does not love her that way.

Just imagine - they think Jon should be assassinated like he was in the season 5 finale for his actions in season 7. Stabbed to death by the men he is trying to save. All because he bend the knee to Dany and fell in love with her.

And they call themselves the real Jon Snow fans

summary: About the idea of a post WW democratic Westeros
title: About the idea of a post WW democratic Westeros
body:
I read a post that talked about the idea that once got the power Jon and Dany could lead to the creation of a modern state in westeros with rappresentation and more peace, I wrote a short answer and then the PC restarted ,so sorry to the post creator but I do not know if you can read my answer :).

I find the idea of a post WW westeros democracy or even a more centralized state not possible, let me explain, the modern state that we have they are not born from nothing, to build a functioning state with a high centralization and a standing army we need many things in history we have two main examples:

the first one is the British in which the nobles and the merchant class slowly (or faster see English civil war) erode the power of the king and gradually concentrate the power in their own hands and at the same time try to develop a strong economy that will later create a new Class, bourgeoisie, large enough and educated that over time will infiltrate the center of power and will start making changes in their favor, and if the economic situation allow it, gradually expand their power in contrast with the power of the nobles.

In the RW the power of the nobility has been increasingly eroded since the birth of the first muskets , that took away from the nobility its base of power, heavy cavalry, the displacement of European military doctrine from cavalry to infantry forced the state to arm more and more men, just think that the French army passed from 45,000 men (max) in the XV century to 250,000 men (on average) in the XVII century, this forced the king to improve the tax system and rise the tax on the nobility ,  and whereas before the nobles could have a good chance of winning in case of rebellion, being theyr knights the base of the royal army, they now had to bow their heads and accept that more and more power passed into the hands of the lower but more efficient classe ,then the king can start to accentralize the state and  at this point we have come to two option :

The first that the king becomes an “enlightened ruler” and begins to use his power to raise middle and high classes and form a “popular” parliament (for example the Prussia of Frederick II) and over time it gives the parliament more and more power and then the goverment become a constitutional monarchy, but in which the king holds a lot of power (example Second German Reich …. only less in the hands of Prussian military), or becomes more a figure to be respected but has limited powers in his hand (modern monarchies). The second is that the sovereign continues to rule with absolute until his “removal” ,(revolutions, coups, assassinations) this will lead to a more or less violent settlement period that will see one of the major classes take over power, and if It is fortunate that this will lead to a democracy.

Average time to form a stable state in RL 3 to 7 centuries with gunpower.    Time in Westeros( with theyr terrible situation , not developt merchant and Guil classes, and with theyr tecnological stagnation  ) who knows.

I think that Dany or Jon can lay the foundations for a  future centralize state but I find it impossible that a few decades can radically change the economic, social and political system of westeros.

I find the idea of a post WW westeros democracy or even a more centralized state not possible, let me explain, the modern state that we have they are not born from nothing, to build a functioning state with a high centralization and a standing army we need many things in history we have two main examples:

the first one is the British in which the nobles and the merchant class slowly (or faster see English civil war) erode the power of the king and gradually concentrate the power in their own hands and at the same time try to develop a strong economy that will later create a new Class, bourgeoisie, large enough and educated that over time will infiltrate the center of power and will start making changes in their favor, and if the economic situation allow it, gradually expand their power in contrast with the power of the nobles.

In the RW the power of the nobility has been increasingly eroded since the birth of the first muskets , that took away from the nobility its base of power, heavy cavalry, the displacement of European military doctrine from cavalry to infantry forced the state to arm more and more men, just think that the French army passed from 45,000 men (max) in the XV century to 250,000 men (on average) in the XVII century, this forced the king to improve the tax system and rise the tax on the nobility ,  and whereas before the nobles could have a good chance of winning in case of rebellion, being theyr knights the base of the royal army, they now had to bow their heads and accept that more and more power passed into the hands of the lower but more efficient classe ,then the king can start to accentralize the state and  at this point we have come to two option :

The first that the king becomes an “enlightened ruler” and begins to use his power to raise middle and high classes and form a “popular” parliament (for example the Prussia of Frederick II) and over time it gives the parliament more and more power and then the goverment become a constitutional monarchy, but in which the king holds a lot of power (example Second German Reich …. only less in the hands of Prussian military), or becomes more a figure to be respected but has limited powers in his hand (modern monarchies). The second is that the sovereign continues to rule with absolute until his “removal” ,(revolutions, coups, assassinations) this will lead to a more or less violent settlement period that will see one of the major classes take over power, and if It is fortunate that this will lead to a democracy.

Average time to form a stable state in RL 3 to 7 centuries with gunpower.    Time in Westeros( with theyr terrible situation , not developt merchant and Guil classes, and with theyr tecnological stagnation  ) who knows.

I think that Dany or Jon can lay the foundations for a  future centralize state but I find it impossible that a few decades can radically change the economic, social and political system of westeros.
